mxfile.agent: 5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/91.0.4472.101 Safari/537.36 Edg/91.0.864.48

mxCell.value: You ignore the path and walk directly into the trees. As you walk, the canopy cover quickly increases and the forest becomes dense. Little sunlight reaches the ground.  You have almost lost sight of the path.

You try  to push the thought of the dog's corpse from your mind with little success. You keep walking. Soon, the shrubbery becomes less dense and opens up into a clearing. There is a crystal-clear blue pool of water, fed by an impressive waterfall.
While clearing your grandfather's attic, you find an old command line computer.

You leave the computer and continue clearing the attic. Later, your grandfather asks if you found anything interesting. You tell him about the computer, and he smiles wistfully. Before bed that night, you see him throwing the computer into the dumpster.
The fan on the computer kicks out dust as it whirs to life. A single blinking line appears on the screen, waiting for input.

"Unrecognized command."
Did you really think that would work?

"list - show files in the current directory
restart - reboot the machine
info - show details about the system"

"- - -  K-OS v3.2  - - -
This sytem has been modified to support the Kern Systems Lunar Expansion.

Connection: offline
C:\ (2GB/2GB)
It's a picture of a man dressed casually in flip-flops, khaki shorts, and a hawaiian shirt.

It's a text file that reads:

"My dear Robin,

You will probably never see this, but I think I've found a way to transmit this out of here. If it works, and by some miracle you do find this and open it, I'm sorry. I don't know how time passes for you. I don't even know what is reality anymore. I can only hope that you haven't been waiting for me for the 35 years that I've been trying to make it back to you. I love you, and I fear that I won't be able to ever make it back. I gave up on the quest five years ago. I just couldn't keep trying to win. It's not possible. Or maybe I just don't have the capacity. If you are reading this, it's time to move on. Don't waste your time looking for answers. God knows I have. There aren't any. I will yearn for you until my dying breath in this place. If I write too much more the file will be too large to send. You are and forever will be my one and only love. Don't play the game."

A program begins to run and command outputs scroll past as text fills the screen. The computer's fan sounds as if it is under intense strain. The monitor flickers to black, and soon the single light bulb hanging in the attic begins to flicker as well.

As the program runs, the single light in the attic goes out. The computer emits a single "ding", despite having no visible speakers. The monitor reads:
"Welcome to The Game :)"

You get up to unplug the computer when the light goes out. The computer emits a single "ding", despite having no visible speakers. The monitor reads:
"Welcome to The Game."

You look around and realize that you are no longer in an attic. You are in a small stone room, dimly lit by a fire in a hearth. In front of you, the monitor continues to display its welcome message, although it appears not to be plugged into anything.
You try to type, but the welcome message remains static. It seems you cannot do any further commands while the game is running.

You type "exit". Below the welcome message, a second line of text appears that reads:
"The game must be completed."
The screen goes black.
A brick hearth houses a small but lively fire. There is no obvious source of fuel.

Overcome by an overwhelming urge of stupidity and masochism, you stick your hand into the lit fire.
You receive second degree burns.
You approach the fire and notice that the embers coming off look different than those you've seen before. They have a slight sparkle to them.

You look more closely around the room and discover a thick wooden door with a metal ring handle. In the dark, it almost disappears into the wall. It looks like it hasn't been opened in a very long time.
You approach the fire and notice that the embers coming off look different than those you've seen before. They have a slight sparkle to them.

You hover your hand above the fire and let the glittering embers hit it. A tingling sensation comes over your hand, and the pain from your previous burns subsides. In fact, the wounds have nearly disappeared. The fire goes out.
Put your hand back in the fire.
You put your burnt hand back into the fire and it now begins to burn on its own. You dance around the room in pain as your crispy hand continues to burn.

You stand up to look around the room, when you hear a loud SLAM. A door that you hadn't noticed hits the stone wall with significant force. A rather sturdy man with a grey beard and lustrous hair stands in the door way. He growls,
"WHO HAS DISTURBED THE FIRE?"

He responds, still loudly, but obviously less intimidated upon hearing you speak:
"Who are you? How did you get in here?"
"I... I don't know. I was on that computer and then..."
You dash towards the door, only to collide with the man. You bounce off of his wall-like figure and hit your head on the ground. As you slip into unconsciousness, you feel the man pick you up.

He interrupts you.
"Hmph. I understand. I'm sorry for my entrance, it's been a very long time since someone like you came through. I'm Earl. I go by Big Earl, though."

You are in a small, cozy, cottage. You can make out a lake through the window. You are in large armchair, made of what appears to be some kind of animal hide. It's very soft. The man speaks again.
"Sorry for what happened back there... you were quite spooked. It's not too safe in that area at night, so I brought you back to my house. Name's Earl, by the way. Big Earl."

"Ah. I see you are a wise man. Well, since the gatekeeper isn't around anymore...I'll get you started. I can't explain much to you now, though. You will have to figure that out on your own. Nobody knows how to win. But I can direct you to people who know more than me. First, you need to get a weapon to protect yourself. Are you more skilled with a sword, or a bow?"

You pull the handle, and the door creaks and moves a bit. With some force, the door swings open in a cloud of dust. You step out into a forest. Daylight streams through the canopy and shows a worn path leading out of the room through the trees.

You follow the path through the forest. You hear strange, bird-like sounds from all around, but you can't see what's making them. The trail winds and twists through the woods, and eventually you see a break in the trees. By now, it is late day. The trail turns to cobblestone as it opens into a field. Ahead, you can see the town.

You ignore the path and walk directly into the trees. As you walk, the canopy cover quickly increases and the forest becomes dense. Little sunlight reaches the ground.  You have almost lost sight of the path.
You go deeper into the woods. It is now almost pitch black. You hear shuffling noises in the growth around you.

As your hand cooks, you hear a loud SLAM. A door that you hadn't noticed hits the stone wall with significant force. A rather sturdy man with a grey beard and lustrous hair stands in the door way. His look of anger disappears as he sees you rolling on the floor, clutching your hand.

He laughs at you, and grabs you by the wrist. With one hand he pulls you off the ground. Before you can protest, he brings your hand over the fire. You wince, but notice that the embers are only tingling your hand. Your charred hand returns to its healthy state and the pain subsides.

The man grunts. He speaks with disapproval and brevity:
"You should leave here. Follow the path through the woods. Have haste, you don't want to be in those woods when it gets dark."
The man leaves before you can say anything. You wish you had gotten his name.
You step out into a forest. Daylight streams through the canopy and shows a worn path leading out of the room through the trees.

You turn around to go back and realize that you can't tell which direction you came from. You start walking towards where you think the path was. You can't find it. You start running. There are footsteps behind you. You begin to sprint, but trip over a large root. You fall and hit your head on a tree. As you lose consciousness, you feel a quite large pair of hands pick you up off the ground.
The woods become increasingly ominous as you walk. Strange sounds put you on edge, but you can't see any creatures in the dark.

You wake up in what appears to be a cottage. It's night-time. The man is knitting something in a rocking chair in front of a glittering fireplace. He sees you.
"Hey you, you're finally awake."

"I'm just doing my duty. Since the gatekeeper hasn't been around for a while, someone's gotta handle the newcomers...you seem confused. It's best not to ask questions now. You'll figure them out on your own soon enough. You should get going before it gets dark. There's a town just east of here. I can bring you there and have you meet some people that will help you on your journey."

You follow the road into a town full of stone-brick buildings with thatch roofs. Thick columns of smoke billow out from their chimneys. Out on the street, various merchants have stands set up that are selling all kinds of odd creatures and objects you've never seen before.
"You'll learn more soon. For now, just know that there are certain things that you need to.

He grabs two long sticks off the wall. One is red, one is blue. They look like they could do some damage.
He opens the door and walks out.

You follow Big Earl out. The two of you follow a winding path through the woods for a long time. Eventually you see a break in the trees. By now, it is late day. The trail turns to cobblestone as it opens into a field. Ahead, you can see a town.
He turns to you and says
"You're on your own from here. Keep going to that town. When you find The Oracle, tell her Big Earl sent you."
Beside you, a dense bushel of leaves suddenly shakes violently. You hear a low growling coming from within.
You hurriedly look around for anything you could use to defend yourself with. You see a thick vine hanging from a tree and a palm-sized stone on the ground.

You pull the vine down just as the creature snarls and leaps out from behind its cover! It gets caught on the vine, and you hold it back while attempting to wrap the vine around its neck. However, the creature quickly chews through the vine and starts to attack you. You die.

You pick up the stone just as the creature snarls and leaps out from behind its cover! You blindly swing and feel the stone make contact with something. With a "CRACK", the creature falls limp. It was a small white dog.

"H... hello? Don't attack! I don't have any weapons!"
The creature's snarls turn into whimpers. After a moment, you see a small white dog limp out of the bush. One of its legs is injured.

With a twinge of guilt, you keep walking without the dog. It's dangerous enough just protecting yourself, how could you take care of a dog? You push the thought from your mind and keep walking. Soon, the shrubbery becomes less dense and opens up into a clearing. There is a crystal-clear blue pool of water, fed by an impressive waterfall.

You crouch down and pet the dog. It has a very worn collar that reads "Marsha". She licks your hand. Soon, the shrubbery becomes less dense and opens up into a clearing. There is a crystal-clear blue pool of water, fed by an impressive waterfall.
Tie Marsha up and drink from the lake..
You find a vine and use it to secure her to a nearby tree. You cup your hands a drink some of the lake water. You feel exceptionally refreshed.
You cup your hands a drink some of the lake water. You feel exceptionally refreshed.
Marsha trots beside you as you cup your hands and drink some of the lake water. She pokes her nose into your hands and laps some too. You feel exceptionally refreshed.

"Ah, a weaponless warrior. I'll bring you into town and introduce you to someone, an old wizard of sorts, who can set you up with what you need."
He moves towards the door.

"That's a good choice. I'll bring you into town and introduce you to the most skilled swordsman this land knows. He'll set you up with what you need."
He moves towards the door.

"Ah, an archer. I see. I'll bring you into town and introduce you to someone, a skilled bowman, who can set you up with what you need."
He moves towards the door.

You follow BEarl outside and take a long, tortuous path through the woods. After a long time, you see a break in the trees. It is now late day. As the forest opens up to a field, you see that the now cobblestone path leads to a town.

You follow BEarl outside and take a long, tortuous path through the woods. After a long time, you see a break in the trees. It is now late day. As the forest opens up to a field, you see that the now cobblestone path leads to a town.

You follow BEarl outside and take a long, tortuous path through the woods. After a long time, you see a break in the trees. It is now late day. As the forest opens up to a field, you see that the now cobblestone path leads to a town.

You follow behind BEarl and enter into a town full of stone-brick buildings with thatch roofs. Thick columns of smoke billow out from their chimneys. Out on the street, various merchants have stands set up that are selling all kinds of odd creatures and objects you've never seen before. You stop and glance at them, but BEarl keeps moving. You jog to catch up to him and see him enter a building with a facade much the same as the rest.

You follow behind BEarl and enter into a town full of stone-brick buildings with thatch roofs. Thick columns of smoke billow out from their chimneys. Out on the street, various merchants have stands set up that are selling all kinds of odd creatures and objects you've never seen before. BEarl walks past them towards a towering cylindrical building, multiple stories higher than the rest, with an impressive spire on top of it. He goes inside.

You follow behind BEarl and enter into a town full of stone-brick buildings with thatch roofs. Thick columns of smoke billow out from their chimneys. Out on the street, various merchants have stands set up that are selling all kinds of odd creatures and objects you've never seen before. You stop and glance at them, but BEarl keeps moving. You jog to catch up to him and see him enter a building with a facade much the same as the rest.

You follow BEarl inside and take in the grandiosity of the building. Bookshelves cover every surface of the walls, and extend all the way up to the top of the building. You wonder how the ones up top can be accessed. In the middle, there is a large wooden desk in the shape of a "U", with various papyrus scrolls and books spread across it. BEarl stops in front of the desk and calls out:
"Nico! I've brought a new entry!"
You hear a thunk and then a groan as a man stands up from underneath the desk. He's dressed in a long tattered robe, with a conical hat that must have once resembled a wizard's outfit. The hat is now limp and bounces about as he talks. BEarl looks happy to see him.
"Ahh, Nico! Long time no see, old friend."
The man, presumably Nico, rubs his head and grumbles a bit, before snapping to attention.
"Oh! Earl! Hello, my friend. Sorry, I was, uh, resting under there. Damn books keep falling down. It's the only place I feel safe."
BEarl chuckles, and puts his hands down on the table.
"Well, it's good to see you again. This recruit is looking for a basic staff. Nothing special, just enough to allow him to channel. What've you got?"
Nico opens and closes various desk drawers before rummaging around in one for a few minutes. Eventually, he procures two knotted wooden staffs. They look identical.
"Okay, I have these two. This one is maple, and the other is birch."
BEarl gestures for you to decide.
A hooded figure, dressed in what appears to be soldier's garbs, sits silently reading a book. The cover indicates that it is a biography of a famous king from this place. He doesn't look up.

You follow BEarl inside a large building filled with contemporary furniture that looks as if it could be easily assembled by any common folk. The building's layout is maze-like, but BEarl seems knowledgeable on the route to take. Soon, you arrive in front of a rugged, bearded man with long blond hair. He speaks with an accent; he is not from this place.
"Hej!" he exclaimed, "How can I help you today, my friend? We've got an excellent new Poäng armchair in stock and going fast!"
BEarl waves his hand.
"I am not here for the wares of your land... I have a new entry who needs something that can skewer a frog from ten feet."
"Ah, I see." responds the bearded foreigner. "Follow me."
"It's a hard maple so it's denser and heavier than the birch. It also looks darker. It's really just for effect, all staffs have the same magical properties.
Nico hands you the maple staff.
Nico hands you the birch staff.

BEarl knocks on the doorway. The man looks up from his book. His face is worn and his eyes show that he has seen war.
"It has been too long, my old friend! How have you been?" BEarl asks the man.
The two of them catch up. The hooded man talks about how he is writing a letter to the printing press of the book he is currently reading. It appears to have something to do with the sizing of the book. Eventually, BEarl asks about finding a weapon for you. The man comes back out with two swords. They look the same, except for that one is gold.
BEarl gestures for you to decide.
The hooded figure gestures to the standard sword. "This one is strong steel. It gets the job done. And this one," He gestures toward the gold sword, "I painted gold."

He hands you the sword. It feels heavy in your hands; powerful.
BEarl thanks the man, and you go to leave. BEarl turns around, just before the door, to say something to the man.
"Oh, and say hello to Noelle for me."

He hands you the sword. It feels heavy in your hands; powerful. The light reflects off the gold coating.
BEarl thanks the man, and you go to leave. BEarl turns around just before the door to say something to the man.
"Oh, and say hello to Noelle for me."
You and BEarl exit back onto the main street. A child runs by you with a duck-billed dog quick in tow. BEarl seems unfazed.

You follow him into a back room. He pulls back a panel to reveal several finely crafted wooden bows.
"For the untrained bowman, I've got..."
He deliberates and eyes a few bows before finally picking up two of them.
"Maple and birch. You won't be able to tell the difference, so the choice is yours."
The man hands you a maple bow. BEarls thanks him and hands over some gold coins.
The man hands you a birch bow. BEarl thanks him and hands over some gold coins.
You and BEarl exit back onto the main street. A man with a lizard's tail passes you. BEarl seems unfazed.
You and BEarl exit back onto the main street. A dog trots buy you and begins to barter with a shopkeeper. BEarl seems unfazed.

You follow BEarl as he suddenly turns into a narrow alleyway. It continues to narrow as you walk, and you begin to wonder whether you will be able to fit through. You then notice a plain wooden door in the wall of the alley. It seems quite unremarkable, but BEarl approaches it. He knocks twice quickly, once, then thrice slowly. A soft voice comes from behind the door:
"What's in a name?"
BEarl responds without a thought,
"A rose by any name would smell as sweet."

The door creaks open.

A lady surrounded by many quilts, fabrics, and silks sits in an intricately carved chair, reading a book. She hums a beautiful tune that you don't recognize. The room is lit only by a fireplace built into one of the walls. It smells like a mixture of smoke and flowers. Wooden beams cross overhead, and the walls are lined in maps and charts that seem to be the routes of various horse-drawn carriages. BEarl clears his throat. The lady, in no haste, places a marker in her reading and looks up.
"Oh, hello. Do I know you?"

BEarl steps closer, and the lady recognizes him,
"Ah, Earl! I apologize, it has been many years since I last saw you."
"I don't know if I'd recognize this face of mine anymore either. These weary years have left me an old man now. Much changed from when we last studied under the same roof."
BEarl and the lady talk briefly and catch up. Then, BEarl speaks of you:
"I've brought a newcomer to you because I think they may finally be the one that the prophecy speaks of. After all these years of fighting and fates, it may be time for the finale."
BEarl's words cause her to rise from the chair and begin rummaging through books that are spread across shelves and tables. Finally, she pulls out a dusty, thickly-bound book. She flips it open to the very last page. The lady speaks to you:
"You must read this for us."

"Through sparks, the One will come into this world. No man nor woman can tell when, but the origin will be of the giving fire. Though alone at arrival, the One will assemble a company of those of the finest character and will. Together, they will journey to purge the greatest evil and find solace in each other. They will become strong together, but sure as the One comes, the One will leave alone and carry that strength forth. Calling upon the spirits of those left behind, The One will bring goodness to every land that lies ahead."

BEarl and the lady are staring firmly at each other. The silence holds a tension. BEarl turns to you.
"It's you."

"You are the One." BEarl says.
"You are the One who can defeat her."

"The dark witch that curses this land." BEarl explains,
 "She's brought hell and suffering to all of us for decades. Pestilence, famine, chaos. She spurs lies and deceit among friends and lovers. We have suffered under her hand too long."
"I don't know if I'm cut out for all of this..."
"You are just one piece of the prophecy. With the rest of your crew, you will be more than capable enough to fulfill your destiny."
"Not alone. You will need the help of truly remarkable people. But they will show you the way to win, and to win on your own.

"We gather your team."
BEarl bids the lady adieu and the two of you exit to the alley. You walk through town and visit various buildings, meeting people who all appear to know BEarl. BEarl tells them to meet at a local pub at sunset. Soon, the sun is only peaking over the buildings.

You and BEarl arrive at a grand, home-style pub. A large sign hangs by the entrance with a small hat on it. Embroidered in gold letters above the doorway is the name of the pub:
<b>"The Tipsy Yarmulke"</b>

The pub opens up into a sprawling and cozy space, equally full of nooks for private talks, and long tables with wooden benches. Candles, lanterns, and the occasional fireplace make it a bright environment. In corners, couples share pints. Groups of old locals talk casually at tables. Joyous laughs come from unseen places and cut through the loot player's melodies. BEarl walks straight to the bar and greets the bartender, who is busy preparing a drink. Time slows as the bartender looks up and makes eye contact, flashing a dazzling smile that could woo the most stoic of people.
"Shalom!" he says.
The bartender looks uncomfortable. Maybe you shouldn't have said that.

He spins a glass in his hand and pulls a tap to pour a perfectly headed pint. He slides it across the counter to you.
"No charge for friends of Big Earl."

BEarl gestures towards a table where a group of people are sat. They look like they come from very different paths of life, and the little conversation happening at the table is awkward and short. BEarl walks over and introduces you:
"Hello, all. I know you all know me, so we'll skip that introduction. This is the One. And I've asked you to be here today, because you're all part of the story. For one reason or another, each of you is irreplaceable in the events that will take place. Although it may not seem clear now, every one of you play a role in making things happen the way they will. Who you are, what you've done, what you can and will do; they all contribute to the profound journey that will change everything, forever."
He pauses.
"Now let's raise a glass... to friendship. Something they can never take away."
You clink your glasses with the group. BEarl continues,
"Oh, and also, drinks as much as you want. Don't worry about payment."
Without asking, the bartender pours you a drink. It's exactly what you wanted.

You and the ragtag group of supposed adventurers begin to loosen up as the drinks keep coming. As conversation livens up, you think about learning a little more about everyone.

Talk to:

You try talking to the man sitting across the table from you, but he is quite reserved. He has brown hair, quite a sturdy build, and lips that could woo even the most unattainable woman. After a bit, you manage to strike up a conversation with him. His name is Alsoums Drau, and he fought with the city's guard for many years. He also sells "some of the finest blades in the land". You take his word for it. Though quiet, you learn that he has a wealth of knowledge regarding the history of the land.

The lady sitting next to you slams a pint, and you try to hide your look of awe. She wastes no time introducing herself. Her name is Harbour, and she's dressed quite fashionably, like nobody else in the tavern (though you can't figure the purpose of the small chain necklace she wears). She claims to be skilled with small blades, but inaccurate at best with anything ranged. She demonstrates this by knocking a glass off the table onto her foot.

To your left, a weary man wearing tattered robes takes a big gulp from his ale. You introduce yourself and find out that his name is Tabacco Czar. You don't have to ask much, because he is already talking without any end in sight. You find out everything from his dental injures obtained in battle, to his romantic affair with some elven creature, to his particular opinions on the beer served at The Tipsy Yarmulke. You're strangely captivated by the man's drunken eloquence.

On the other side of the table sits the lady that BEarl introduced you to, when you learned about "the prophecy". She's wearing a sort of strapped tunic that is embroidered with some ancient, reptilian creature. You don't learn much about her, but she does mention her studies of old writings and the public carriage transportation network.  She seems out of her element here, but is more than happy to converse with the rest of the adventurers.

The lady sitting next to you slams a pint, and you try to hide your look of awe. She wastes no time introducing herself. Her name is Harbour, and she's dressed quite fashionably, like nobody else in the tavern (though you can't figure the purpose of the small chain necklace she wears). She claims to be skilled with small blades, but inaccurate at best with anything ranged. She demonstrates this by knocking a glass off the table onto her foot.

You find out everything from his dental injures obtained in battle, to his romantic affair with some elven creature, to his particular opinions on the beer served at The Tipsy Yarmulke. You're strangely captivated by the man's drunken eloquence.

On the other side of the table sits the lady that BEarl introduced you to, when you learned about "the prophecy". She's wearing a sort of strapped tunic that is embroidered with some ancient, reptilian creature. You don't learn much about her, but she does mention her studies of old writings and the public carriage transportation network.  She seems out of her element here, but is more than happy to converse with the rest of the adventurers.

The lady sitting next to you slams a pint, and you try to hide your look of awe. She wastes no time introducing herself. Her name is Harbour, and she's dressed quite fashionably, like nobody else in the tavern (though you can't figure the purpose of the small chain necklace she wears). She claims to be skilled with small blades, but inaccurate at best with anything ranged. She demonstrates this by knocking a glass off the table onto her foot.

On the other side of the table sits the lady that BEarl introduced you to, when you learned about "the prophecy". She's wearing a sort of strapped tunic that is embroidered with some ancient, reptilian creature. You don't learn much about her, but she does mention her studies of old writings and the public carriage transportation network.  She seems out of her element here, but is more than happy to converse with the rest of the adventurers.

The lady sitting next to you slams a pint, and you try to hide your look of awe. She wastes no time introducing herself. Her name is Harbour, and she's dressed quite fashionably, like nobody else in the tavern (though you can't figure the purpose of the small chain necklace she wears). She claims to be skilled with small blades, but inaccurate at best with anything ranged. She demonstrates this by knocking a glass off the table onto her foot.

To your left, a weary man wearing tattered robes takes a big gulp from his ale. You introduce yourself and find out that his name is Tabacco Czar. You don't have to ask much, because he is already talking without any end in sight. You find out everything from his dental injures obtained in battle, to his romantic affair with some elven creature, to his particular opinions on the beer served at The Tipsy Yarmulke. You're strangely captivated by the man's drunken eloquence.

To your left, a weary man wearing tattered robes takes a big gulp from his ale. You introduce yourself and find out that his name is Tabacco Czar. You find out everything from his dental injures obtained in battle, to his romantic affair with some elven creature, to his particular opinions on the beer served at The Tipsy Yarmulke. You're strangely captivated by the man's drunken eloquence.

On the other side of the table sits the lady that BEarl introduced you to, when you learned about "the prophecy". She's wearing a sort of strapped tunic that is embroidered with some ancient, reptilian creature. You don't learn much about her, but she does mention her studies of old writings and the public carriage transportation network.  She seems out of her element here, but is more than happy to converse with the rest of the adventurers.

You try talking to the man sitting across the table from you, but he is quite reserved. He has brown hair, quite a sturdy build, and lips that could woo even the most unattainable woman. After a bit, you manage to strike up a conversation with him. His name is Alsoums Drau, and he fought with the city's guard for many years. He also sells "some of the finest blades in the land". You take his word for it. Though quiet, you learn that he has a wealth of knowledge regarding the history of the land.

On the other side of the table sits the lady that BEarl introduced you to, when you learned about "the prophecy". She's wearing a sort of strapped tunic that is embroidered with some ancient, reptilian creature. You don't learn much about her, but she does mention her studies of old writings and the public carriage transportation network.  She seems out of her element here, but is more than happy to converse with the rest of the adventurers.

After a bit, you manage to strike up a conversation with him. His name is Alsoums Drau, and he fought with the city's guard for many years. He also sells "some of the finest blades in the land". You take his word for it. Though quiet, you learn that he has a wealth of knowledge regarding the history of the land.

The lady sitting next to you slams a pint, and you try to hide your look of awe. She wastes no time introducing herself. Her name is Harbour, and she's dressed quite fashionably, like nobody else in the tavern (though you can't figure the purpose of the small chain necklace she wears). She claims to be skilled with small blades, but inaccurate at best with anything ranged. She demonstrates this by knocking a glass off the table onto her foot.

You try talking to the man sitting across the table from you, but he is quite reserved. He has brown hair, quite a sturdy build, and lips that could woo even the most unattainable woman. After a bit, you manage to strike up a conversation with him. His name is Alsoums Drau, and he fought with the city's guard for many years. He also sells "some of the finest blades in the land". You take his word for it. Though quiet, you learn that he has a wealth of knowledge regarding the history of the land.

BEarl ends a lengthy conversation with the owner of the pub. You overheard bits and pieces; they seemed to be talking about some sort of cost-benefit analysis. BEarl comes over and speaks to the group:
"Looks like you lot are are getting along alright. You've all got a long day ahead of you tomorrow, so get some rest for an early start. We'll meet outside The Yarmulke at sunrise. And pack well, you might be out there for a while."

You go back to BEarl's and he shows you a small cot to sleep in.

Early the next morning, with nothing but your weapons and a small rucksack, you say goodbye to BEarl and head towards town. BEarl stops you on the way out the door.
"Be careful. Your faith in yourself may be shaken at times. Use the others. Let them anchor you, and be there for them. You must be strong alone, but you will find that first, you must be strong together."
You arrive at The Tipsy Yarmulke and see that you are the last to arrive. The others have leather armor, weapons, and large packs. You feel woefully unprepared.
Nobody responds. The group looks uncomfortable.
Alsoums informs you that his name is not, in fact, Stanley.
Alsoums gestures to the Oracle, who unfolds an intricate map on yellowed parchment. There is an X drawn over the summit of a mountain on the map. You realize you never got her name.
After a moment, the Oracle unfolds an intricate map on yellowed parchment. There is an X drawn over the summit of a mountain on the map. You realize you never got her name.
After a moment, the Oracle unfolds an intricate map on yellowed parchment. There is an X drawn over the summit of a mountain on the map. You realize you never got her name.

"Antesolo. Most people just call me Antesol."
You nod. She continues,
"We should start walking. I want to get to the base of the mountain before it gets dark. We need good rest if we're going to make good time climbing. Everyone, ready?"
Antesol starts walking down the path that leads out of town.

"I'm just doing my duty. Since the gatekeeper hasn't been around for a while, someone's gotta handle the newcomers...you seem confused. It's best not to ask questions now. You'll figure them out on your own soon enough. You should get going before it gets dark. There's a town just east of here. I can bring you there and have you meet some people that will help you on your journey."
"You'll learn more soon. For now, just know that there are certain things that you need to.

He grabs two long sticks off the wall. One is red, one is blue. They look like they could do some damage.
He opens the door and walks out.

You follow Big Earl out. The two of you follow a winding path through the woods for a long time. Eventually you see a break in the trees. By now, it is late day. The trail turns to cobblestone as it opens into a field. Ahead, you can see a town.
He turns to you and says
"You're on your own from here. Keep going to that town. When you find The Oracle, tell her Big Earl sent you."

A narrow alleyway draws your attention. You walk down it as it continues to narrow. At the end, there is an old wooden door. You get a feeling that this is the right place. Hesitantly, you knock on the door.
No response.
You knock again.
Nothing.

After a moment, a voice asks,
"What's in a name?"

The voice mutters with exasperation.
"BEarl... never tells them anything... it's not 'mysterious', it's annoying."
The door swings open.
A woman stands tiredly.
"Well, come in."

The lady sits in sits in an intricately carved chair, surrounded by many quilts, fabrics, and silks. She hums a beautiful tune that you don't recognize. It seems sad. The room is lit only by a fireplace built into one of the walls. It smells like a mixture of smoke and flowers. Wooden beams cross overhead, and the walls are lined in maps and charts that seem to be the routes of various horse-drawn carriages. She begins rummaging through books that are spread across shelves and tables. Finally, she pulls out a dusty, thickly-bound book. She flips it open to the very last page. The lady speaks to you:
"You must read this for me."

"Through sparks, the One will come into this world. No man nor woman can tell when, but the origin will be of the giving fire. Though alone at arrival, the One will assemble a company of those of the finest character and will. Together, they will journey to purge the greatest evil and find solace in each other. They will become strong together, but sure as the One comes, the One will leave alone and carry that strength forth. Calling upon the spirits of those left behind, The One will bring goodness to every land that lies ahead."

The lady turns to you.
"It's you."

"You are the One." She says.
"You are the One who can defeat her."

"The dark witch that curses this land." she explains,
 "She's brought hell and suffering to all of us for decades. Pestilence, famine, chaos. She spurs lies and deceit among friends and lovers. We have suffered under her hand too long."
"I don't know if I'm cut out for all of this..."
"You are just one piece of the prophecy. With the rest of your crew, you will be more than capable enough to fulfill your destiny."
"Not alone. You will need the help of truly remarkable people. But they will show you the way to win, and to win on your own.

"BEarl will help send you off. I will show you the way to return to his cottage. Tell him what I have told you."
With that, you exit back onto the street.
You walk out of town, following the path you came in on. It's getting late in the day, but you should be able to make it to the cottage while it's still light out.

You arrive at BEar'ls cottage and knock firmly on the door. You hear his footsteps as he makes his way over to the door and swings it open. He looks displeased to see you.
"Why have you come back here?"
 He asks in a tired tone.
You hate yourself for even thinking about saying such a disgusting sentence. What you actually say is...

BEarl's expression suddenly changes.
"Come in."
BEarl moves towards another room.

He sits in a sizeable leather armchair with a serious look on his face.
"I wasn't sure if the day would ever come...I suppose now there's only one thing to do: we gather your team."
BEarl gets up, puts on a fur coat, and leads the two of you into town. You walk through the cobblestone paved streets and visit various buildings, meeting people who all appear to know BEarl. BEarl tells them to meet at a local pub at sunset. Soon, the sun is only peaking over the buildings.
"One last thing," BEarl says to you,
"You'll need this."
He hands you an old sword. It looks like it has many years of history in it.

You set off walking with the team. Soon, you can only seem a few distant plumes of smoke rising from the town on the horizon. You walk through a field of wild wheat. The sun warms your skin and a breeze rustles the stalks around you.
Ask Antesol about the maps on her wall.
You watch his limp conical hat bounce with each step. You note that it seems to fit with his general character.

"I've a particular interest in the coordinated carriage transport that runs around the town. The operators have developed a surprisingly complex system to make it as efficient as possible, and they've made it quite accessible too. I, myself, enjoy riding the carriages often.  I consider it one of the best public transportation systems in the land, as my maps have shown. "

You continue walking. All of a sudden, Alsoums holds his hand up in a fist. The group suddenly stops. Tabacco walks into you from behind.
"What's that sound?" he asks.
You hear the tall stalks of wheat begin to rustle all around you. Alsoums draws his sword and looks back at the group,
"Have you ever fought a field before?"
Before you can get an answer, you feel something wrap around your leg.

You unsheathe your sword and swing it at the tendril of wheat grasping your ankle. It slices cleanly through. You look around to see the others being attacked by dozens of animated stalks. You're surrounded. Alsoums cuts down one after the other in a flurry of strikes. Tabacco uses fire and sparks to keep them at bay. Two vines wrap around Harbour's ankles and start to drag her out into the field.

You load an arrow into your bow and take aim at the tendril of wheat grasping your ankle. With surprisingly accuracy, your shot arrow cuts through the stalk and embeds itself into the dirt. You look around to see the others being attacked by dozens of animated stalks. You're surrounded. Alsoums cuts down one after the other in a flurry of strikes. Tabacco
uses fire and sparks to keep them at bay. Two vines wrap around
Harbour's ankles and start to drag her out into the field.

You grab your staff and point it at the tendril of wheat grasping your ankle. With a bit of thought, you summon a small flame that burns through it. You look around to see the others being attacked by dozens of animated stalks. You're surrounded. Alsoums cuts down one after the other in a flurry of strikes. Tabacco
uses fire and sparks to keep them at bay. Two vines wrap around
Harbour's ankles and start to drag her out into the field.

BEarl pauses and looks away.
"No. It wasn't."
You sense a sensitive subject and don't ask any more questions. You turn the sword over in your hands, observing its gleam. The wooden handle has the name "Alex" etched into it.
"Big Earl. A very important man from a long time ago...now he has taken up a life of solitude, guarding the gate."

Alsoums yells over his shoulder while fighting
"If they take her too far we'll never see her again! Someone's got to get her!"
You run towards her, but the stalks pull her away as you get closer. You loser her into the field, but you can still hear the wheat rustling.
The others are busy protecting themselves from the onslaught of living grass. Harbour's cries fade into the distant crops.

You strike the stalks down as you run away from the group, out into the field. You feel them lash at your ankles and try to block your path, but you are able to clear them as fast as they can appear. After what feels like eternity, you catch up to Harbour in a clearing in the field. The wheat has grouped together to form a giant humanoid monster. Harbour is behind it. It swings one of its giant hands towards you.

You attack the oncoming stalks until, finally, the group of you are surrounded by dead plant matter. Alsoums surveys the damage.
"Is anyone hurt?" He asks. "Where's Harbour?"

Alsoums looks at you and knows.
"Oh." He pauses. "Did anyone see them take her?"
His voice wavers. You can tell he is holding back his anger.
"You tried? Here's a thought, how about next time you try to DO something! We're not here to work for you. You have to take responsibility. You could have saved her."

Alsoums moves his gaze around the group. "I expect better from all of us. We should have had her back. We could have saved her."
He looks down at his feet.
"We can't stay here. We should still be able to set up camp by the mountain tonight. Let's go."
"Sorry isn't enough! Sorry doesn't bring her back."

The four of you get going. It's much quieter than before. A gloom hangs over the group.

Shortly, the field is behind you. You wish the memories were too.
"I didn't mean for this to happen."

"None of us did. We should have done better." He looks down at his feet.
"There's no going back now, and we can't stay here. We should still be able to set up camp by the mountain tonight. Let's go."

With a bit of straining and thought, you point your staff at the Straw-man and launch a small fireball. The flames appear to do little damage to the monster, other than a small hole in its chest. The beast raises its arms above its head, and you brace for a heavy hit. But it stops short, and lets out a wounded roar. You notice flames climbing up its back, and soon, the being begins to crumble to ash as the growing fire incinerates it.
You strafe to the side just as the hand smashes into the ground where you stood before.
You crouch down, but the hand catches your shoulder and throws you off your feet. You hit the ground hard, and in a daze. You know you'll be sore later.
You roll out of the way, moments before the hand smashes into where you were just standing.

You lunge forward and swing your sword through the abdomen of the Straw-man. It cuts through, but the monster still stands. You take a step back, and then run towards it. With a massive jump and a well-placed strike, you behead the thing, and its body goes limp as the grain returns to its ordinary, vegetative form. Harbour steps forward from behind it. She seems unharmed.

You draw your bowstring back and send an arrow flying into the Straw-man's eye. It rears back for a second, but is otherwise unfazed by the arrow stuck into its hay-like body. Your weaponry is ineffective against such a beast. You look around to see if there is anything else you could use, but there is nothing but field. You hear a rustling behind you...

Suddenly, you hear a crashing as something bursts out of the field into the clearing. You hear an exuberant calling out of "Shalom!", and see a man soar through the air beside you. He lands on one knee with a fist in the dirt. Its the man from the bar. He stands in front of the wheat creature.
"What's the matter? Not enough hops?"
The bartender dashes behind the monster and climbs up its back with ease. Then, with nothing, but his bare hands,
tears its head from its neck and tosses it aside. Its headless body falls limp and returns to its normal plant form.

"This one," he says, "is on the house."
He helps Harbour up before speaking again.
"Lucky I was here. I only caught up to give you this. It was left at the Yarmulke."

"No." he says, as he helps Harbour up.
"I saved her."
He checks that she is okay before speaking again.
"Lucky I was here. I only caught up to give you this. It was left at the Yarmulke."
It takes less than an hour to reach the base of the mountain, but it feels like eternity. The gargantuan mound of rock looms above you, but a modest river keeps it from spilling over towards you.
You thank him as he dashes off back towards town. It must be a busy life, tending a thriving pub.

You bring Harbour back to the group. They all let out a sigh of relief upon seeing her safe return.
"We need to be more careful." Alsoums says.
"We got lucky this time. Next time it could turn out much worse."
You move towards the pile of ash as Harbour rises out of it, like some kind of clumsy Phoenix. She coughs, but is otherwise unharmed.
Return to the group with Harbour.

It takes less than an hour to reach the base of the mountain, but it feels like eternity. You keep hearing her voice in your head. You wonder if you will ever have quiet in your mind again. You wonder if guilt burrows deep into the brains, leaving its hook permanently in your subconscious. You shake the thoughts for the moment and work on setting up camp with the others. The gargantuan mound of rock looms above you, but a modest river keeps it from spilling over towards you.

You look around the perimeter of the camp and find enough tinder to get a small fire going. You prop up a small log next to it and sit down. As the others finish putting up their hide tents, they join you around the fire.

You look at Tabacco staring into the fire. There must be something on his mind.
"What do you do, normally?" you say. "I mean, when you're not going on epic quests to save the world."
He sits up and straightens his hat. It falls down again.
"I'm usually holed up in my tower, studying magic. The books keep me company, even if they're a bit bitey. Sometimes people come in looking to buy some item they heard about on the streets. Sometimes I have it, sometimes I don't...I like the quiet. All this fighting is a bit surreal to me. I worry that someone will get hurt.

You look at Tabacco staring into the fire. There must be something on his mind.
"What do you do, normally?" you say. "I mean, when you're not going on epic quests to save the world."
He sits up and straightens his hat. It falls down again.
"I'm usually holed up in my tower, studying magic. The books keep me company, even if they're a bit bitey. Sometimes people come in looking to buy some item they heard about on the streets. Sometimes I have it, sometimes I don't...I like the quiet. All this fighting is a bit surreal to me. I was worried that someone would get hurt, and now Harbour is gone."

"I'm sorry. I should have saved her."
Tabacco looks into the fire.

"I worry too. The hardest part is that all we can do now is be better, and keep going. I don't want to let her death be in vain."
Tabacco looks into the fire.
"Yeah."
There isn't much talk around the campfire tonight. Soon, it's nothing but a small flicker. The rest of your crew slowly heads off to bed. You sit and poke the coals with a stick.

"I worry too. And there are some things we can't control. Something could happen, someone could get hurt. But we can do our damned best to be prepared, and to look out for each other. I think that's all we can really do."
Tabacco nods.

"We'll be okay, don't worry. I'm sure of it. We've got one hell of a line-up."
Tabacco is unmoved by your words.
Slowly, the chatter around the campfire dies down, as do the flames. Everyone heads to bed. You kick some dirt over the coals and go to your tent.

The sun comes through your tent flap. It's early. You step outside to see Alsoums and Tabaccco are sitting by the fire, cooking some kind of game on a cast-iron skillet. You're not sure where the skillet came from, but it makes for a nice scene.

Soon, you reach the foot of the mountain. The stone behemoth towers over you, only kept at bay by a modest river in front of you. Alsoums tells the others to set up camp where you are. You all get to work.

You look at Alsoums. He has a stern face, like always.
"What do you do, normally?" you say. "I mean, when you're not going on epic quests to save the world."
He looks back at you with no change in facial expression.
"I fought with the town guard. 15 years..." he pauses, "It never gets easier."
You don't know what he means. "What gets easier?"
He just looks at you.
You know what he means.

You look at Alsoums. He has a stern face, like always.
"What do you do, normally?" you say. "I mean, when you're not going on epic quests to save the world."
He looks back at you with no change in facial expression.
"I fought with the town guard. 15 years..."
He pauses. "This is much better."
You nod, despite not knowing much about what being in the armed guard is like.

The sun comes through your tent flap. It's early. You step outside to see Alsoums and Tabaccco are sitting by the fire, cooking some kind of game on a cast-iron skillet. You're not sure where the skillet came from, but it makes for a nice scene.

You sit down on a log by the fire and Alsoums offers you some meat. He says it comes from some kind of animal called a "Marsha". Reluctantly, you accept. It's actually quite delicious. You chat with the two of them about ales while the rest of the crew takes down the camp.

You find Antesol in her tent, doing some writing on an old parchment. You ask, "Do you know anything about what's going to happen? With the mission? Since you're an oracle..."
She looks like she's been asked this before. "I only know the prophecies, there's never specifics." She waits a second before asking you a question of her own: "Has Alsoums mentioned me?"
You tell her you can't recall it, but you don't really talk to Alsoums. She seems sad.
You go out to the camp center and see Alsoums kicking some dirt over the last flames of the fire. He's got his leather bag on his back. It looks heavy. He turns to address the group:
You chat with them for a while, until Alsoums leaves to take down his tent. He comes back with his leather bag over his shoulders. He turns to address the group:

"Alright. We need to cross this river before we can start up the
mountain. Can't swim. Too deep, too fast, and we're too heavy with all
of our gear. Any ideas?"

Alsoums nods. "That's not a bad idea... it may take a while though. Okay. Harbour and Antesol, you two gather as many vines from the surrounding forest as you can carry. The rest of us will get logs. Big ones; to last together.

Alsoums furrows his brow. "Tabacco... you got any magic that will help us across?"
Tabacco thinks for a second.
"Well... I've got one thing that might work. It'll be hard though."

"There's a very difficult spell that allows me to control the temperature and pressure at which a certain region exists as a state of matter."
Everyone looks confused. None of those words exist. He clarifies.
"Air bridge."
Everyone nods in understanding. Tabacco continues:
"I'm going to need everyone to listen very closely, and do exactly as I say.

It takes about an hour of foraging, but soon enough you all stand beside a large pile of sturdy logs and thick vines. You start arranging the wood into a raft shape while the others lash them together. It's hard work, but by noon you have a fully assembled, make-shift raft.

"I need to concentrate and focus completely on casting the spell. I will wait on this side, and when you see the air over the river start to shimmer, you can cross one at a time. I can only support one of you at once. Cross as quickly as you can, straight across. The bridge will be just wide enough to fit you. I can hold it for 30 seconds, maybe a minute at most. Once everyone is over, I will cross."

Alsoums lines you up. Alsoums first, to test the safety. Then Antesol, then Harbour, then you, and finally Tabacco. Alsoums looks back at Tabacco, and he nods. Tabacco closes his eyes and begins to concentrate deeply. Wind appears where there was previously no gust, and it all converges towards the river. The water goes from a lackadaisical lull to white caps. A thin space of air over the river begins to shimmer slightly. The morning sun distorts around a rectangular outline. Alsoums starts to walk towards it, hesitantly. He puts one foot out into the air...

Alsoums lines you up. Alsoums first, to test the safety. Then Antesol, then you, and finally Tabacco. Tabacco closes his eyes and begins to concentrate deeply. Wind appears
where there was previously no gust, and it all converges towards the
river. The water goes from a lackadaisical lull to white caps. A thin
space of air over the river begins to shimmer slightly. The morning sun
distorts around a rectangular outline.
Alsoums starts to walk towards it, hesitantly. He puts one foot out into the air...

He lowers it down to be met with solid "ground".
"All good!" he calls back.
Tabacco is still focuses. Alsoums carefully, but quickly, makes his way across the bridge. Once he is on the other side, he calls for Antesol. A bit slower than him, she steps over. She is almost at the other side when a huge wave crashes up over the bridge. You hear a yelp, and lose sight of her behind the water. You gasp. Not another. Not like this. The mist dissapates, and Alsoums has caught her wrist as she dangles above the treacherous river. He pulls her out and to safety. That was close.

He lowers it down to be met with solid "ground".
"All good!" he calls back.
Tabacco is still focuses. Alsoums carefully, but quickly, makes his way across the bridge. Once he is on the other side, he calls for Antesol. A bit slower than him, she steps over. She is almost at the other side when a huge wave crashes up over the bridge. You hear a yelp, and lose sight of her behind the water. Harbour gasps. Not another. Not like this. The mist dissapates, and Alsoums has caught her wrist as she dangles above the treacherous river. He pulls her out and to safety. That was close.

He lowers it down to be met with solid "ground".
"All good!" he calls back.
Tabacco is still focuses. Alsoums carefully, but quickly, makes his way across the bridge. Once he is on the other side, he calls for Antesol. A bit slower than him, she steps over. She is almost at the other side when a huge wave crashes up over the bridge. You hear a yelp, and lose sight of her behind the water. You gasp. Not another. Not like this. The mist dissapates, and Alsoums has caught her wrist as she dangles above the treacherous river. He pulls her out and to safety. That was close.

She seems unsure, but steps forward anyway. Putting one foot in front of the other, she crosses the bridge. But you worry about how much time she is taking. They said we only had a minute at most. It must be getting close. Slowly, Harbour nears the other bank of the river. She steps onto real ground and you feel relief wash over you. Now it's your turn.

Not sure of how much longer the bridge will exist for, you begin crossing with haste. About halfway across, you notice something on Tabacco's side of the river. A giant frog has hopped out of the woods and is meandering worryingly close to Tabacco. You fear it may confuse him for a bug.

You move to the far side of the bridge with the others. You all call out.
"Tabacco! Tabacco! Watch out!"
He can't hear any of your over the roar of the river. The realization settles in that there is nothing you can do anymore. With one movement, the massive frog opens its mouth and propels its tongue towards Tabacco. Briefly flung forward and then pulled into the beast's gaping mouth, he is gone as quickly as he was here. The bridge dissapears. The wind dies down, and the river calms once again. You and the group look in shock. There are no words. Antesol drops to her knees. You look the other way.

You turn on the spot and run back across, shouting for Tabacco as you run. He snaps out of his spell-casting and sees the frog. In an instant, he conjures a spray of fine salt grains towards the large amphibian. It jumps high into the air, rearing back in pain. You tackle Tabacco, just as the frog lands where he previously was. The frog hops away into the forest. You sit on the ground beside Tabacco, out of breath. He slaps you on the back.
"Thanks, brother." You just nod.

With the help of the others, you carry the raft over to the river bank and place it in. Alsoums holds it place while you and Tabacco board. It floats. Alsoums shoves the raft and you kick off the bank. You arrive safely on the other bank, only a hundred feet or so down-river. After a few more trips back and forth, you're all ferried across. You pull the raft out and leave it on the shore. Maybe it'll help someone else out in the future.
